We walk to the beach every morning and in about 1-2 minutes we are on the beach. Shopping is right at your doorstep, as are clubs in the evenings.

Great location and our room had a nice view. Friendly staff through out the hotel and restaurant. Our wing of the hotel was dated, carpets were worn,the walls in the room needed to be repainted and the furnished was worn.Bathroom small and shower was adequate. Bed was comfortable.As our flight was leaving later in the day we had the use of a hospitality room to freshen up before departing Hawaii, which was much appreciated.

We are just back from Oahu and, as usual, stayed at the PK. We love the location and the friendliness of the staff. This time, we got our room and the AC wasn't working. We called and they promptly sent someone to check it. It still wasn't great so we went to see if we could switch rooms. Not only did they switch us, but gave us a high floor with a gorgeous view. Just can't say enough about how nice that was. The staff was very friendly and really worked at making us happy. Ping, Alex and the front desk crew: Shanna, Herbie and Debbie at the Splash Bar all made us feel right at home. And, Wing in room service was very friendly. A great hotel that works hard at making your vacation memorable.

Stayed for a week in June 2014 and used a Travelers cc card when checking in. Great Hotel, Great Staff around pool, restaurant, but CLUELESS STAFF AT RECEPTION. Upon Checkout, they maxed out my travelers cc card and forced me to pay for all my room charged items via another CC. Upon checking my statement, found they already charged all room charges and who knows what else (Un-Authorized items) to my card, and to date, have not received a refund. Still battling to get my money back.

OMG! My first trip to Hawaii couldnt have been more perfect than it turned out! My partner D. Judd n I celebrated our 20 yr anniversary in this beautiful place! We stayed here at the beautiful Sheraton PK from 9/24-9/30. We were not disappointed in the least. To start with Tammy, the gal who checked us in was great! When we first booked our reservation, after requesting a king bed thru Bookit, they had us with 2 double beds, Tammy caught that n gave us a room with a king bed in the tower. I would have liked a higher floor, but we got a room on the 5th floor above the pool n we were quite satisfied. After getting settled in, we got on with our trip. We enjoyed the poolside bar. Debbie, our day waitress, was so funny n just spot on keeping us takin care of. She's definitely a keeper! Now, I didnt think this Hotel was that dated, actually I felt it quite modern. Our room was cozy, the bathroom was a bit small, but beyond that, the bed was super comfortable, the view was good, and housekeeping made sure our room was clean everyday, n we had coffee n lots of water! BIG shout out to ur housekeeping team! The Hotel was perfectly located close to restaurants, stores, n best of all, The Beach!! We didnt take advantage of the buffet...but enjoyed an afternoon meal poolside. Btw, very good food! Mo, ur evening bar waiter was perfect!! He remembered exactly what i drank, so when we stopped by he asked if i would like my drink...now thats service! Arthur, ur Bell Captain..was just superb! We wanted to take a tour around the island limo style, n hooked us up with a super guy..for a great deal! Mahalo Arthur! This was a beautiful adventure n vacation, so much Island beauty! I hope we can make another trip back next year! I wish i could remember every employee that helped in some way or another, but All in all, Princess Kaiulani, was a perfect place to stay!! Thank U for ur warm Island hospitality!

Alright place if you can get a great price. The hotel rooms desperately needs to be remodeled.Good location though and close to the beach. Not on the beach but not a problem.Lots of construction on both sides of the hotel so be prepared for noise.

Stayed five nights, booked with short notice and so room was best available for price, but very basic. Small bathroom and comfortable beds were pretty much all that was in the room. Everything was clean & well maintained, but felt dated. Quick shortcut past the pool through the sister hotel across the road onto Waikiki. There is a major construction site next door as the International Market Place is demolished...I think they will coincide a renovation to occur during the period. I imagine you could get a better deal to include the breakfast, but overall the staff were lovely and that is what you want when you stay anywhere. Hotel was in a handy spot to beach, shops, bus stops, restaurants in fact everywhere. Downside were the lifts, which were a little slow in the peak traffic times.

We have just returned from 2.5 weeks staying all over Hawaii and stayed 5 nights in the Sheraton Princess on Waikiki. I felt that this hotel was the best value for money that we got the whole time. You couldn't ask for a better location in Waikiki for the $ value and we had an ocean view room looking over the pool which was perfect. The service was great and we used the wii fii that came with the resort fee so can't comment on the timed computers in the lobby. Nor did we rent a car so can't comment on valet or car park. The pool is lovely and doesn't feel overcrowded at all (like it does at the Outrigger). We were out all day either in the pool, wandering the restaurants or at the beach so the construction noise next door wasn't a problem for us but if you are someone who likes to stay in your room then yes the noise of construction would get irritating but this is my only negative comment! I highly recommend this hotel for value and location.

After reading some of the reviews, I think some people are either spoiled or just out of touch with reality.First, I have seen people complain about the $26 room fee. Friends stayed at another upper end hotel, their fee was $36 a day, no breakfast. We got two per day, rooms always cleaned daily and 2 bottles of water and coffee/tea replaced every day.Second, staff was friendly and helpful, even found my wife's expensive sunglasses and had them waiting on us when we returned from an outing. Third, yes it is dated a bit, but clean, great location, we were on the beach in 5 minutes, only 100 yards from the property. I didn't have that much trouble with noise, it is a big city, expect some.Fourth, the rooms were laid out and signs posted where your room is when you exit the elevator. just take 30 seconds to read them.Fifth, never have had to have a certain paper, i.e. Wall Street Journal or other delivered to me every day. I am on vacation. if you want one, there is an ABC store 50 feet in either direction.Sixth, you want a robe, take one with you...lol Really? $225 a night in that location? We did get a free drink at the bar, guess I should complain because it wasn't of my choosing, but hey, I'm easy to please. This is Hawaii, everything costs more. Our friends paid $280 a night, plus $36 resort fee, no free breakfast. (valued at $24 by them, but even at $13 each was worth the room fee). if you get a chance, want a nice hotel, stay there. Highly recommend it. To me its one of the best values for the money.

Stayed three nights at this hotel.It is over-priced in terms of hotel room price vs. value, breakfast, and the resort fees.No welcoming gift at all for Platinum guests.No Upgrades for Platinum guests.No courtesy to extend late check out, mind you that almost ALL of your mainland guests fly back to mainland on flights departing after 7-8pm in the evening. Are you expecting them to hangout all afternoon and evening at airport?Not recommended!

Aloha, We stayed for an overnight stay... The Front Desk was nice and polite..The room was amazing... 29th floor... Great View... Construction Noise next door property was loud in the day time... Meals: Pikake Terrace was expensive for dinner $42. for a buffet... Good Selection of food, Quality of Food was very good. Staff : Susan, Felix, Debbie - Outstanding ... Breakfast Buffet $25 was more reasonable. Live Music in the Evening...

First the good.1. They have both NHK (TV Japan) and PBS available on their television.2. You are allowed 45 minutes on their lobby computers, if you can log on.3. The continental breakfast is very ample.Now the Bad1. The $26 resort fee covers a continental breakfast for one (count them one) day, we stayed 3 days, tough stuff on the other 2 days.2. The resort fee covers parking a real plus since most tourists fly in and do not have a car.3. No Wall Street Journal, and they could not get the local paper to my room, they did get my wife her Nikei Shimbun.4. Halls not marked with direction for rooms when you get off elevators, leads to lots of wandering around with luggage to lug.5. The hotel is 50 years old, and it shows.6. Royal Hawaiian is 100 years old and very well maintained, with a light continental breakfast in the Azure Dining area each day for the resort fee.7. Room service prices are outrageous, how dumb do you think I am?8. We had lunch in the bar area, the soup and caesar salad were both so salty that we stopped eating after two bites and went over to the Sheraton Wakiki to buy bento at Lawson Station.9. Good size room, but very noisy and we were on the 17th floor. Single glazed windows so we heard every motorcycle, ambulance, fire truck coming down the main street, and every garbage and delivery truck in the morning.10. No bath robe, for Christ's sake do you think I am going to steal it?11.No meal available in the evening unless you will pay $42+ for a buffet dinner, give me a break.12. Spring for the extra $100 and stay at the Royal Hawaiian don't waste you money here.

I've been a long time traveler staying at many hotels for work and pleasure; had platinum status at Marriott and SPG. I stayed at the Marriott Waikiki and Moana Surfrider in the past and I must say this is one of the worst hotels for service. The parking attendant gave me grief about the parking pass; that's because I didn't get one during check-in. The same check-in person said i'll get a bottle of wine but that never happened. The tissue paper box was empty and never replaced, no bottles of water as part of the resort fee (two bottles per day). Called about it, waited an hour and still no tissue box or bottles of water. Had to call again before someone would come up and deliver it. The hotel rooms are dated and the toilet seat won't stay up. It drops if you don't hold it up, warning to guys, don't let the seat catch you like a snapping turtle. The parking lot has no elevators but I knew this because Moana Surfrider shares the same parking lot.Overall, i'm surprised at the quality from a Sheraton and SPG branded properties. Will be looking forward to checking other ones in the future.

This hotel is a great location but the construction from the International market place is very loud, stay on other side if you can. We used a third party booking agent "Orbitz" which was fine, great price but be warned upon check in that if you want any change like a room away from construction, or say two beds they want to charge you a huge upgrade fee. We went and looked at the upgraded room for $60.00 more a night and it was identical to the one we had booked except higher floor with two beds overlooking the construction site. We did not take the upgrade, too loud to even sit on balcony. The check in guy kept saying we would have to contact Orbitz he could not help us. I called Orbitz and they were very helpful, got the manager on the phone and suddenly we got the two beds we needed on a lower floor without the upgrade fee.

I stayed 5 nights. The location is central Waikiki and is convenient. The service was decent. My room had a small oceanview. However, I have to say that for dining and lounging, we went to other hotels with better views and higher quality. I don't have any particular grudges or anything but the hotel along with many other places in Waikiki needs updating. The bathroom smelled bad when I would run the water, a sign of old plumbing. This is not what I expected of a Sheraton.

My wife and I stayed here for 8 days as a 2nd honeymoon. We loved it. The service was great, location is the best and it was so easy to find somewhere quiet to relax.The gym was simple but had all one needs to keep toned during a holiday. The room was adequate, who comes to waikiki to spend time in the room anyway, and the bed was firm and super comfy. Will definitely stay here again and recommend to friends and family. Mahalo.

Despite the negative reviews, still booked here and enjoyed my stay.. not for honeymooners, book the other Sheraton for that type of nicer occasions, but great for all others.. great location, right across the street from all the beachfront more expensive properties.. rooms are a little outdated, but the open air lobby connecting to the pool is cool, and was never too crowded.. pool side exit access to the main street which is a plus, free parking included with resort fee, no elevator, no big deal, be smart and swing through the front turnaround and drop off your bags before parking.. some cool evening entertainment near the pool was nice, worst part was the construction still on the side of the property, something is being built and not even close to completion, a little noisy at times.. front desk staff is understaffed, patience is necessary... corner room 2061 ocean view was nice.. in closing, if you can pay $100 dollars less incl. fees in comparison to the other Sheraton, Moana, Hilton, Hyatt, Outrigger, etc... and get a guaranteed ocean view this place is worth it..

We stayed at this hotel over the Labour Day weekend (2014). We were very happy with the location, but we were disappointed by the state of the rooms. the entire hotel could use a refurbish. the furniture and decor is dated and a result does not look overly clean.We were initially put in a pool view room of the Princess tower (one of the two lower and I presume older towers in the hotel). After one night there we went to the front desk to request a better room as that room seemed more Motel 6 quality than Sheraton quality. To their credit, after a discussion where I emphasised the room was not of the standard we expected, they did move us to a room in the newer higher tower. We were on the 27th floor facing north east.The room was definitely nicer and the patio was larger and the view was very nice. Even though the second room was better than the first, we still don't feel it was up to Sheraton standards.The housekeeping and maintenance staff were very pleasant and helpful. We did have an issue with the lock on the new room. Security came quickly to confirm that we were the right people trying to get into the room and to determine the problem. Once the problem was diagnosed, maintenance had it fixed in a timely manner.If you choose this hotel, our suggestion is that you insist on a room in the newer, taller tower.

Reviews on this property varied when I made the reservation, but we opted to go with it due to the central location in Waikiki. Location was perfect! Right across the street from the beach, King's Village, etc. Lobby was open to the pool and outdoors, and just lovely. Staff the greeted us were full of Aloha and friendly! Then we got to our room .... old, musty, and HOT. The bathroom looked like one from a hospital - certainly did not have the feel of a resort or nice hotel. We could not adjust the A/C at all, and in the middle of summer on the 8th floor was super hot. Was very, very disappointed with the room. The "resort charge" of $26/day was a little ridiculous for water bottles and parking (website had initially said "free parking"). There was free WiFi access (included with resort charge). We didn't use the pool or beach amenities, so can't comment on that. Would I stay at this hotel again? Maybe .... they are in need of a renovation, and an A/C system that works. Staff was super nice, very responsive, and pleasant. Beds comfortable and clean. Good price, and I can't say enough for the location!!!

The location is perfect!! Mins from Waikiki beach and marketplace! We rented a car to go around and that helped a lot! The weather in February was great except one shower! At the hotel the breakfast was delicious and plenty! We had a great time, at the hotel there are hula classes and making flower garlands for free!

This was our third stay at this hotel and, as usual, it was an enjoyable stay. Very helpful staff, especially when you are a Starwood Preferred Guest and although the facilities are a little outdated, the hotel is clean, quiet and has interesting activities each day. It is a couple of minutes walk to the main road fronting Waikiki Beach, but there is a good-sized pool on the premises if you do not fancy the beach. Although if you stay in the Waikiki area why not visit the beach with all the water-based activities available? Waikiki has a large range of shopping and eating places to suit all tastes and pocket books! Due to its location and reasonable prices, the Sheraton Princess is not short of patrons, so it is advisable to book well in advance of your visit.

Location, location, location. This says it all. You get a good price compared to the sister hotel Westin Moana across the street but this hotel is definitely showing its age. It was supposed to close for a $500 million renovation but this never happened so they did superficial renovations in the lobby to spruce it up but rooms, fixtures, elevators, etc are old. This hotel needs a complete makeover in order to bring it into the 21st century.Hotel staff were great and they treated me well as a platinum guest. Parking in the garage is horrible as there aren't enough parking spaces for the Westin and Sheraton Princess. Be prepared to drive around in circles for a very long time trying to find parking

We just spent ten days at the PK, and despite reading many reviews, our summary is that the location, friendly staff all over the hotel, bar and dining experience all outweigh the dated roomsOur room was cleaned spotless everyday, and we'd have no hesitation in staying here againVery comfortable beds, nice size room, great air conditioning, nice balcony and lovely to spend time by the poolAnd all this right in the middle of Waikiki being just minutes to all on offer

One of the best Beatles tribute bands here on Oahu. You'll experience 90 minutes of music that will take you back to a time when everything was good and simple. There isn't much to do at night for baby boomers so plan on spending a Tuesday, Thursday or Saturday evening with Fourever Fab. There is audience participation and you'll be on your feet clapping and singing along. We have seen many tribute bands and these guys are worth a second look. Aloha and Enjoy!

Excellent location and lobby is beautiful. Beach service is fantastic. However what really lets this hotel down is the rooms and floor corridors. Rooms are very outdated and poor on cleanliness. Much nicer hotels to stay in!!!

The over priced resort charge is not worth the extra dollars ($26 per day) One could buy their own beach towel each day for this price. Fruit was either an apple or orange. The beach trolley was hard to find and not on the beach at 10am. Apparently the converge said they are at the beach at 11.30 and 1.30pm. Excellent position but the view from my room was a car park.

I travel frequently to Honolulu and need a hotel in Waikiki that has all the amenities and won't break my budget. The Sheraton Princess Kaiulani is a perfect match. It is located one block from the beach in Waikiki, so it is very centrally located. The Princess Kaiulani provides an excellent combination of tourist amenities and mid-priced accommodations. This hotel is suitable for tourists as well as business travelers. The Princess Kaiulani strives to create a Hawaiian haven in the middle of busy Waikiki. The lobby has been recently renovated, so now the feel of the lobby is more Asian than Hawaiian. However, considering the number of Japanese tourists who come to the beautiful state of Hawaii, this is not surprising. Renovations need to continue, nevertheless, the Princess Kaiulani provides excellent value for the money. It is my hotel of choice when I stay in Honolulu.

They have a 'new look' in the Lobby - it looks fantastic with more seating areas in the Lobby area. Great to see that they put the 'buffet' area all on one side of the hall-way. Now you do not have to dodge people with plates of food as you head for the elevator. Someone reviewed (Kim146) said it was close to the International Market - - - which is there no longer. It is completely gone after many many years as a Shopping Landmark in Waikiki. Which means that side of the Hotel can be noisy with the new construction going on. A 'must' in the area is the 'Farmer's Market' across the street on certain days (after 4pm). Also a 'must' is having cocktails and snacks at the Moana Hotel Beach Bar under an over 100-year old Banyon Tree (just across the street).

Sure the hotel was outdated and when I booked my room the site said the same, that renovations were coming in Sept. 2014. But the renovations needed did not change the fact that this property sits at a fantastic location. Was the pool great? Sure was. Were the room's clean? Sure were. Did we have a good customer service despite walking on outdated carpet to get to our room? yes, we did. We were on the 18th floor facing Diamond Head, not even 'Premium Ocean View' and the view was spectacular. Shower was great despite the renovation and updating needed. We were not 'Beach side' but were sure close enough. I would come back after renovations to see this hotel in it's full compliment.

This hotel was affordable and was in terrific proximity to the International Market, is across the street from Cheesecake Factory, and easy access to freeway back to HNL, about a half hour or 45 minute drive. A van to the airport will pick you up at this hotel for a reasonable paid fare. The staff was marvelous and I learned the day I was checking out that they teach you how to make leis in the hotel lobby. I missed this but would have loved to have experienced this. They have a very nice and clean swimming pool. Overall, was only 2 blocks from the beach (an easy walk)and a perfect location!

I would like to thank you for the comfortable stay with you during our honeymoon for 2 weeks and the lovely touch sending champagne bottle for us.The hotel is in great location but a bit old and needs a lot of improvements specially the room doors. The rooms are in small size and had a tiny view of the ocean. Also there is additional daily charge for water, internet and towels in the room as for a resort it should be included with the rate but that's extra $24 a day, it's not a pleasant way to overcharge. What hotel doesn't provide towels for free! The food and beverages are overpriced specially the open buffet dinner. However; we really enjoyed the breakfast & nice touch when you check in they give voucher for continental breakfast, but we anyway decided to pay for the hot breakfast as well. The staff are very nice at the breakfast and very helpful.Tourist information desk is excellent, specially Tommy many thanks for helping us plan the activities. We only been on the pool area once, the pool is in average size, it could be improved, isn't very inviting. The bar is overpriced and they have the ads around the hotel about happy hours that includes some cocktails but on the bar they only offer beer and wine, 2 cocktails would cost at least $20 elsewhere there is always cocktails offered in happy hour period. Good luck and hope to visit you again.

This hotel is nice. Has a nice lobby, a nice bar, nice pool, nice employees - but it is dated. It hasn't had a room renovation. Ever. the furnishings, wallpaper etc are from the 70's and it just feels old. My A/C in the room would NOT get cold. it lets you set it to 65, however it NEVER gets colder than 71. It would cut off during the night and we would wake up sweating. Also the internet is hit and miss. sometimes it wouldn't work for hours. Other than than that it was clean and pleasant and the employees are excellent.

Being brand loyal travellers, my husband and I had no hesitation in booking into this hotel online. We have previously stayed in 3 other Sheraton properties in Honolulu, and wanted to try this one. Having done so, it would be our last choice of Sheraton properties in Waikiki, not so much because it was "bad", but because it was just old, basic and bland. It mystified us why Sheraton keeps this particular hotel in its portfolio here.It is absolutely true however to remember that while this hotel lacks the spark and Aloha spirit of its sisters the Moana Surfrider and the Royal Hawaiian, it is much less expensive, and it is still centrally and ideally located. While staying here you are easily able to access some fabulous dining and shopping options just outside the front door, so if you are wanting an affordable and convenient place to sleep this may suit you very well.

How is that possible you say? Well, after walking into room 579, how can you be anything but? View of the parking lot and trash bins; old, worn, dirty grout in the bathroom, small room, door locks not working (not good for a woman here alone). I tried to book a better room but it wasn't available. However from the reviews, I'm probably better off not paying the extra money anyway. Upon check in the young man at the desk wasn't very helpful, even when I told him it's my birthday and I'm here alone because I have to attend some business meetings. I requested a room on a higher floor away from the elevator so I could rest when I got done with my day-long meetings. He could care less. My room wasn't ready at 2pm, all he kept repeating is "check in is at 3pm"! This is the first time I've ever come to Waikiki one hour before check in time and I was told the room wasn't ready(and I've been here 3 times in the last 6 weeks, but at a different hotel), but maybe they are that busy! I have to say that the young lady who gave me the keys at 2:50 (I decided to ask if the room was ready a little earlier once I saw another desk agent was available) was extremely nice and tried to upgrade me but said the rooms were all booked. She also offered to send a complimentary bottle of wine to my room for my birthday! Now that's Aloha service! Someone train the other kid quick or let him go. Anyway, I digress! Today is my first day here and I avoided coming back to the room for as long as possible so I don't have to sit in this dreary room for too long! Lesson learned- next time I'm going back to my usual hotel! I thought I'd give is a try because someone in my company had said they stayed here before! Maybe they got a better room? Either way, I don't recommend this to anyone unless you really have no place to stay. Really disappointing experience from a Sheraton and a Starwood resort!Oh yeah, the two stars are for the location!

Upon checking in, its clear that the lobby has been upgraded. However, speaking strictly regarding the two rooms we stayed in at the old section (not the tower rooms) I was surpized at the level the room was kept. The walls were bare except for a picture on one and a bath robe hook (?) in the middle of another one. The furniture had to be from the late 1970/s and was beat enough to show every year of use. The bed was comfortable and standard for Sheratons, but even the bathroom was of a caliber more associated with a Super 8 than a Sheraton. Again, the tower may have been renovated, but the main hotel rooms were obviously never touched. Keep this in mind if you stay here. Many people say when they visit Hawaii, its not about the rooms but the closeness to the beach. If thats the case, then this might fit your needs. However, usually one stays at a Starwood for the room as well as the location. Not strictly the location. On that note, it is across the street from the Moana Surfrider and in a good location for a quick walk to both the beach and for shopping. Its just that when I stay at a Sheraton, I expect more than what these rooms had to offer....wow...

I stayed here from Aug 8 to 14, 2014. The rooms are old and in need of much renovation. The grout in the bathroom tile needs to be cleaned. Overall the service and the people at this hotel were very nice. However, the rooms are just really small and old but serviceable. I would compare the quality of the rooms to probably a La Quinta Inn room or worse. This hotel is in an excellent location as it is right on the Kalakaua strip and right in the middle of that strip. From the hotel, you can walk pretty much anywhere.Overall, this hotel is average and decent but not worthy of the Sheraton name brand.

Situated across the street from the beach, this hotel is in an excellent location on Waikiki. There is also an emergency medical center inside the hotel. It is surrounded by plenty of excellent restaurants. I wouldn't suggest using the hotel buffet as it is very expensive however the items on the regular menu are priced reasonably and are very good. The Honolulu Coffee that is located right outside the pool area is decent but very expensive (Starbucks is cheaper). There are three towers, each with distinctively different rooms. The biggest tower at 29 floors have excellent rooms while one of the other towers have significantly smaller rooms. Rooms are clean, come with lots of towels, hair dryer and lots of pillows. Staff are very friendly and helpful. If I needed anything, it was promptly attended to.There was live entertainment every night. It was usually a band in the evening and a one man show with a guitar at the hotel bar towards the later hours of the evening. You could not hear this from most rooms and did not disturb in any way. I would say this entertainment is geared towards the older crowd and as such would not consider this a party hotel but better for business travelers, families and couples. There was some construction by the hotel which disturbed some during the day however it didn`t bother me. As expected, there is street noise if you sleep with the balcony door open.

It was our fourth time back to the Princess (duiring our 25 trips from New York to Hawaii). This hotel is more reasonable than others in the Oahu Starwood family and affords a choice of various views from individual lanais. Although we love the ocean view, the pool view offers a view of nightly entertainment from the comfort of your own room (request poolview with view of the stage minus palmtrees). The hotel offers a Starwood dine-around option and parking is included in the mandatory resort fee. Rooms are comfy with a frig. Housekeeping is very friendly and helpful. The pool is a good size and the pool guy is great! (The only criticism really was that management should tell the young male lobby personnel to be alot more attentive to the needs of ALL quests...it seemed they could not be bothered to give us directions, say, to a local street two blocks away or address our other questions.) The hotel is nicely located to public transportation (we use bus passes all the time and rent a car occasionally to travel to the North Shore) and is across the street from the beach. It is near the pick up for the free HIlo Hattie shuttle and many fine restaurants and entertainment as well as shopping. The Princess is adjacent to the New International Marketplace, scheduled to open 2015. (We love Saks, but we mourn for the return of the old marketplace vendors and eateries under the old Banyan Tree that were truly a tourist delight....I quess Trump and the Outrigger have started the trend to upscale Waikiki and thus it continues; but we feel it is at the cost of Aloha!) The Princess is a place of abundant history, so ask if they still have tours of the hotel and its sister property across the street, the Moana. This hotel offers a good taste of Hawaii at a resonable price. We have stayed in dozens of hotels throughout the Islands and plan to return to this one again on one of our future trips.

This is the second time I have stayed at this hotel, both times booked & paid for by my employer. Both times the rooms were very noisy & the aircon hardly worked. The bathrooms are very dated.The second stay was for 6 nights. There was a group of 13 of us staying and it took just over 90mins from arriving to get our room cards, even though we had rung ahead from the airport around an hour before arriving at the hotel! A complimentary cocktail was "compensation" for the delay.The room was "cleaned" daily, but that merely consisted of emptying the rubbish bin, making the beds, & changing towels. Although on 2 days only some of the towels were actually changed. We had the complimentary water & coffees re-stocked most days. Twice the cleaners attempted to enter the room prior to knocking, and both times were prior to 8:30am (not unreasonable to still be in bed at that time).As a positive, the front-of-house staff were very friendly & the pool/bar area was good to relax in when I had the chance. Plenty of places to eat nearby & the beach is a block away.If not for my employer making the bookings, I would not be staying here again.

We stayed here on our honeymoon and the budget we were on this hotel fit the bill. We had a nice high floor and were on the end, so we had great views of the ocean from our room. The walk to the beach is nonexistent (literally right across the street) so it was ideal for us and our vacation. The other hotels in our price range were down further away from the beach and honestly didn't look as nice. We were impressed with the room and the amenities. The pool isn't very large, but that didn't bother us because the ocean is just a few feet away! I would definitely stay again.

I booked a room at this hotel for a 4-day stay in Honolulu with my family, mainly because of the location, as well as the 3-star rating and beautiful photos of the hotel facilities. While the map did not lie - the location is great, the story told by the pictures was a lot less veracious. The hotel is not horrible, but my low rating reflects as much a disappointment of my expectation as the issues with the hotel.Upon check-in we were told that our ocean-view reservation was upgraded to a handicap accessible room, which would provide a better view. The room was on the 12th floor of the western tower, facing east, with the views of the ocean, east Waikiki, Diamond Head, and the hotel courtyard, and these views were indeed spectacular. It was quite noisy - despite the 12th floor, the noise from the street traffic, the evening shows on stage in the courtyard, and the nightly performances of the street dance crew right outside the hotel measured at 77 dB on the balcony. The sliding door in the room did not do much to block the noise. This door did not do much to block the heat either - coupled with the aging, poorly designed AC system, the room was always hot and very humid, even after running a whole night. The only modern part of the electrical system was the thermostat, which was smart enough to shut the system off while we were out of the room, so we could not leave it running to keep the room cool for when we come back, which made for a very miserable experience.The room was quite small, and the two double beds did not leave much room for the chair and the vicker armchair, making it feel cramped. The bedding was clean and the comforters fluffy, but the pillows were not supportive at all. Both beds were slanted to one side, and the mattresses would easily slide to the side off the boxspring, making the person sleeping on the hanging-off side feel like he was about to fall off. Flat sheets, which were not long enough to wrap around the foot of the mattress, would untuck the moment we pulled out the bed covers to get into bed.The carpets were old and grungy, and other than the view through the sliding door, which was great, the room decor would be best described as 1960s low-end - it did not look redecorated since being built. The room had a flat-screen TV, a mini-fridge, and a safe which did not work. The closet had sliding doors with paint which was beginning to peel off, and the entry door also looked a bit warped and peeling. The real disappointment was the bathroom, which was described to us as handicap accessible. It had a warped barn-style door, with the sliding track on the outside. Because it was not straight, and had layers of peeling paint, it would not seal off the odors or the humidity of the bathroom, which incidentally has no exhaust vent. In service of accessibility, the bathtub was replaced with a plastic enclosure with a straight curtain rod running straight above the edge. With the grab bars protruding from the wall side, there was not enough shoulder room to shower without rubbing against the curtain. The bottom lip did not contain the water inside the shower enclosure, so it was running on the floor, until we thought of barricading it with the towels. The towels were thin and small, so we ended up using pool towels for showering also. The counter was old and worn out. The faucet used to be painted white, but the paint had peeled off from about half of the metal, furthering the dumpy feel of the room. The door couldn't lock, or even slide fully closed.The building has ~30 floors (there are two other buildings which make up the hotel). It had 4 small elevators, one of which was broken for half of our stay. It was hardly surprising, as the elevators seemed in poor condition from the start, with the indicator lights burned out and not replaced (this is a former elevator engineer talking). Still, to get up we had to wait 15+ minutes to fit into the elevators, and to go down during the evening rush hour took even longer. After waiting for 20 minutes, we decided to take the stairs, only to discover that they were disgustingly dirty. We mentioned the broken elevator to the clerk at the front desk, whose reply was "Oh, really? I will see what we can do" - nothing was done during the rest of our stay.Our hotel stay turned out to be an interesting multi-cultural experience - other than ourselves and a small contingent of Canadian soldiers on the islands for a military exercise, every other guest at the hotel seemed to be Chinese. They have a higher tolerance for being packed sausage-tight into the elevators, which you pretty much have to do even with all the elevators in service. Not being used to the high-rise living, I found the experience to be annoying, and the excruciatingly long waits to get into the elevator only raised my anxiety levels.The lobby is clean and spacious, but open to the outside, so you feel all the humidity and heat with none of the cooling breezes of being out on the street. The staff were friendly, even if not always helpful. There was a buffet breakfast ($25) and dinner ($40-42) served in the lobby restaurant - I think normally this restaurant is operating in another part of the main floor, which was being refurbished.The main floor opens up on the courtyard, which has a fairly large pool with lounges, a poolside bar with tables, and a stage, where most nights there were live performances. The hotel bills itself as a resort, and charges a little over $26 per day of a resort fee (including tax). This is a good value, as it covers the parking, internet, pool towels, and usage of the pool and other fitness facilities. You can also borrow a beach chair to go to the beach, which is not quite across the street, but is really close. Apparently, they also have a beachside fruit service for the hotel guests twice during the day, though we haven't experienced it. One issue is that some of these resort facilities, usage of the pool, towel exchange, beach chair rental, close very early in the evening - most nights at 7 PM, and some nights as early as 5. This means that you need to tailor your schedule to that of the hotel, rather than it being the other way around, as I feel it should be at a resort. Despite all these gripes, the hotel is in a central location, with the street below full of high-end stores, much like Rodeo Drive. The evenings are full of energy, and the sidewalks are full of pedestrians (mostly Asians), street performers, and homeless people. There is a small stage by the beach, where there are Hawaiian-themed performances. The beaches are packed with people, and the wave-breakers make for a very calm water to wade in, save for all the people splashing. There is an ever-present swarm of surfers a few hundred yards out in the ocean, beyond the breakers.Being in the thick of things is both a blessing and a curse - all the food establishments there, including low-priced chains like Subway, KFC, Burger King, McDonalds, carry a hefty tourist premium. Originally I thought that this was the case everywhere on the islands, but the last day we ventured to the south-east end of the island, away from the touristy areas, and discovered that the same chains were only slightly more expensive than the mainland, and significantly cheaper than Waikiki. Another issue is traffic congestion - there is a lot of it everywhere in Honolulu, and even more so in Waikiki. There is a lot of one-way streets, and the main drag has an interesting arrangement of lights, which favors pedestrians over vehicles. This makes even a seemingly short trip take a long time. While the distances are generally short, going anywhere requires you to make an arduous trek to the freeway (which has a speed limit of 35-45 mph most of the way through the city). This hotel is good if you are after the experience of the tourist vibe, proximity to the beach, and the nighttime entertainment. On the other hand, if you are looking for rest and relaxation at a beachside resort, I would recommend you look elsewhere.

My wife took me to Hawaii in December 2010 (could not select that date) for my birthday and we used it as our honeymoon. I've stayed at the Sheraton PK several times over the years and I never get tired of this place. Staff is friendly, rooms are always great. Just about any room I've stayed in I've had a great view. But I don't go to Hawaii to stay in the rooms. The hotel is close to Dukes and the beach. After swimming in the ocean and having some sun, it's time to bar hop. Every day, we, literally, walked from Dukes all the way down to Barefoot bar at the HaleKoa, having a drink a few times along the way. One day we walked the other direction down to the Elks - hands down one of the nicest Elks lodges anywhere - we found it easier to take a bus after that day, however...it's a bit of a hike.
user_name:
Brian F
Cathedral City, California, United States

review_body: We stayed on the 27th floor of a newer tower with a water view. The room was smartly furnished with a lanai with visitors (birds) stopping by when we were eating in our patio. This place was very central to exactly where we wanted to go. The beach is less than a 5 minute walk and if you wanted to go for a morning run by the base of Diamond Head it's an option. They also offer self park, but the only downside is that it doesn't have a elevator.Pros: Nice views in our towerCons: Washroom toilet was difficult to flushShower head didn't have much pressure

I stayed at this hotel for 14 days. My first room was on the 7th floor with a lovely view of the garage and a tarp covered trash bin. I could see the mountains on my left but that was it, the room itself was OK ..two double beds as requested. The furniture was shabby, the bathroom fixtures worn and some of the wallpaper needed to be repasted. Small things that would not have taken a lot of time to fix. In must say the pool was great ,,free towels, Popsicles and cool wash rags throughout the day. The location for eating, shopping and the beach was great. The restaurant was not so great, the buffet was waaaay overpriced, and service poor. Also, the buffet is on the way to the elevators and the smell, especially on the seafood buffet was nauseating at times. it should be moved!!I upgraded to a room on the 26th floor, and for an extra $40 a day got a fantastic view. However , again the room and the furnishings were very shabby. I did complain about the desk chair (it looked as if had been gnawed upon by a large dog) and it was quickly replaced. The lady at the front desk was very helpful, or so I thought. The initial transfer of rooms took quite a long time due to some internal snafu, and she said she would send up cookies as a thank you...said cookies never arrived, even after I stopped by twice to remind her. Disappointing.The cleaning needs to be more thorough...the edges of the furniture should be dusted and the floor needs to be vacuumed more often. I had sand in my room from the first day I used it and it never got vacuumed the whole time.This was my first time in Honolulu..would I stay here again? ....doubtful when I see the other gorgeous hotels around. The location is good, but noisy.

The SI was in great condition. they were doing some painting in the lobby area, but it was not a problem. the bar and pool area were very nice as were all of the staff. Everything very clean. It was a great location as once I parked the car I could walk about everywhere. A small outdoor mall across the street with some cute restaurants. Beach just a block away. I would definitely recommend.

room is quite old but overall experience is okay! location is perfect! next to the international market and just 1 block awsy from the beach. we stayed at a high floor partial city and sea view room. and it is awesome!

The room was great! Big thanks to Crystal in reservations. Very comfortable bed and an amazing view of the ocean and part of Diamond head. You can also see Koko Head off in the distance. We were celebrating our anniversary so we went out to dinner. When we got back, there was a bottle of Cabernet and two glasses waiting for us.

Having read the reviews about this hotel before we went, to be honest I was actually dreading staying here. Now having actually experienced this hotel myself I have to say some people need to get over themselves. This hotel is great. Great location, excellent staff, lovely rooms (if not a little dated), genuine all round great stay. There is some modernisation being undertaken right now, which, when completed, can only enhance your stay. We had no problems at all staying here. We had a room on the 5th floor of the main block (not tower) overlooking the pool area. We had a great balcony, if not a little small, with a partial view of the ocean. Yes the pool is a little crowded, and perhaps too small for a hotel of this size, but who needs a pool when you have the entire Pacific Ocean a couple of hundred metres away? The only downside I have is the resort fee. Definitely not worth the money unfortunately, you'd have to go some to get the value out of it. A few bottles of water and free internet access does not warrant $25 per day I'm sorry to say. At least consider a pay as you go resort fee that way people are only paying for what they actually use. Otherwise I would definitely stay here again in a heartbeat.

This is an older hotel from the 60's, and even with renovation, it shows its age. Location is perfect but its a block away from the beach. Lobby areas are really nice but the valet areas are very crowded and often impossible to get your car in as you try to check in. Before you get to the front, you may be stopped by some "time sharing" venders so be aware. Rooms are rather small and view we got was looking toward the east with a glimpse of Diamond Head. Maybe other rooms could be better. But the price was good. Pool is nice and lots of room to relax with a nice bar. However it seems it gets shaded by other tall buildings nearby, making it not very inviting and even too cold in December.Location is great to all the shops and dining. Beach is very close within a minute or two across Kalakaua Ave. Next to International Market and Kings Alley and shopping complex of Hyatt Regency.

We stayed here in late 2011, so we knew it was a good location. This time we had a high oceanview room (level 20) in the tower and the views were amazing. This is an older hotel and looks a bit worn in places, but it's still a great place to stay just across the road from the iconic Waikiki Beach.The staff here are friendly and very helpful, we couldn't fault them at all. The hotel seems to have had a bit of a makeover since our last visit, partcularly in the reception area.Now, there are a couple of negatives...The restaurant is way overpriced. You can find better eating within a five minute walk at a MUCH lower price.The other negative is the 'Resort Fee'. This was, I recall about $12 - $13 per day in 2011, now its $25, a 100% increase, for what they describe as 'valuable extra services'.In reality, these are nothing of the kind....internet access, which is generally free in hotels around the world, parking (great if you actually have a car to park), a couple of bottles of water in your room every day, AND, if you are on the beach at the right time (times vary) an extra bottle of water and an apple or orange (your choice). Woopy Doo! And that's the extent of these 'valuable extra services'.My personal opinion is that that the resort fee is way too much and is simply a grab for extra dollars. We have decided that as a matter of pinciple, and solely due to the resort fee, we will not return to this hotel.That said, apparently the Moana Surfrider across the road is charging a $50 resort fee. Wow! Who's silly enough to pay that?
user_name:
David L
Sydney, New South Wales, Australia

review_body: We stayed here for 5 days. We were never in our room. Room is ok size. The bed and the carpet were older and needs some TLC. It was right in the middle of Honolulu. I prefer to stay away from the Honolulu. But if it is your first time stay somewhere around here. The price was decent for this area. Its near the Westin Moana Hotel which has a nice bar we liked and near the beach.

If you're looking for a beach resort to hang out, this is not the place for you. But if you are looking for a reasonably priced, good quality Waikiki hotel where you can sleep and clean-up, this is a good choice. Granted this hotel is older and a bit warn. But they are remodelling and should look fresher soon.The hotel is located right in the heart of Waikiki along with many high priced and crowded hotels. You can walk up and down Waikiki rather easily and it's right across the street from the beach. But the best part is that parking and internet use is included in the hotel's resort fee. OK - all of the hotels charge a resort fee now, so accept it. And $25 to park your car in Waikiki and have internet access is a deal. It also includes beach towels, etc. Also, the parking lot is easily accessible off the side streets, Kuhio or Ala Wai, so you can get in and out of the Waikiki area faster.

Marsha at the Travel Desk was a wonderful find. She booked 4 tours for myself and my family. Marsha was a font of useful local information and each tour exceeded our expectations. It was our first visit to Honolulu and Marsha was very patient and considerate when dealing with our older passenger nervousness. It is fair to say that our great enjoyment of your island was greatly enhanced by the kindness and professionalism of Marsha.

My wife and I stayed here this past June as the start to our honeymoon. We booked through a travel agent for 5 nights and the location of the hotel was excellent. Our main complaints are that the rooms are dated, the front desk was not accommodating and there was massive construction next door. To start with the rooms, it was clear that nothing had been updated since the 80's and it was pretty small. The view from our side of the hotel was a giant construction project right underneath us. When I asked to change rooms to avoid the eyesore, the hotel wanted to charge us an upgrade fee because there was nothing of equal value available on the other side of the hotel. In terms of the help, one front desk employee; Jahan was actually terrible. He was difficult to work with when we ordered food to the hotel, refused to heat it up for us and then canceled our taxi to the airport without letting us know. He did all of this even though on arrival we gave the front desk our cell phone number and let them know all of this would be happening. There are much better choices close by that are worth checking out...don't need to stay here.
user_name:
Jesse B
Forest Hills, New York

review_body: Ive stayed at this hotel, probably about four times. Mainly because of the location, pretty much across the street from waikiki beach, and they had a back enterance to the international market, which is sadly not there anymore. I love the koi pond, feels like old hawaii, hopefully they will keep when they eventually remodel the hotel itself. Second to the last time we stayed, we had to change the hotel rooms three times, the first one the A/C was leaking, the second time, something else was wrong. The front desk staff are friendly and helpfull, and they will move your luggage for you to your new room, if unfortunately you do have to switch. We have ate breakfast there once, and it was quite good, all the waitresses and the omellete chef was fanstastic. Ok, so its hawaii, a lot of the restuarants are open to the outside, yes there are birds, get used to it!

We picked this location based on the location in the heart of Waikiki and special pricing offered at the time of booking. There were some mixed reviews on TripAdvisor. We were a little concern about our stay but it turned out to just be great. We still decided to stay there knowing that wherever we traveled on vacation we spend most time out.RoomWe booked a partial ocean view and got upgraded on arrival without making any request to a deluxe ocean view with a decent balcony in the highest floor. The bathroom was just right. The bed was nice. We had a great view for photo ops.Overall lookThe hotel is obviously old but have some nice decoration inside. We took several pics.NoiseWaikiki is a busy place and the hotel is very popular and the traffic is non-stop. The hotel was full when we were there and we could not hear anything from the room next door. Maybe it depends on the room you get.ServiceWe had several interaction with the staff and found them professional. OverallAt some point during our stay, my wife and I wondered about all these bad reviews on TripAdvisor that we could not validate. Oh well, maybe it is all about everyone expectations and personal experience. Maybe we got lucky this time...It is still hard for my wife and I to get all these negatives about this hotel. We have traveled to many places in the world, read the reviews on TripAdvisor and mostly agreed with most reviewers. This won't be the case here.

Great shopping in an open air centre. All the shops you could want in one location. There are also great laces in eat and it is very family friendly. Open till late every night. Also a grocery store in the centre to pick up any times you may have forgotten to pack.

I have stayed at this hotel three times in the last six or so months with a combined stay of 16 nights so i can say I have some experience with staying at this hotel.Firstly, this is not to Sheraton standard. Rooms are date, walls are thin, you can hear what going on in the room next door.There's a construction site next door at the international market and the noise is incredible!I can accept the hotel being dated and run down but I can't accept the poor service I received on my last two stays from front office staff and the manager on duty.We had workman drilling into concrete on the floor directly above us at 8 am in the morning the day after we arrived and the front office staff knew nothing about it nor where we advised that works were to take place. I'm an SPG Platinum member but have not been treated worse at any other Starwood hotel than i have at the Sheraton PK.If you're planning on have a relaxing time in Waikiki, stay somewhere else.I'm happy to talk to the hotel manager about my experience should they wish to contact me.

My girlfriend and I did a girl trip to Hawaii including a cruise. We arrived in Hawaii at different times as we were coming from different areas. We booked through her travel agent (she will never use them again, nor I or anyone else in our party). I arrived earlier and found out that her name was the only one on the reservation so they would not let me into the room. I had to hangout for 7 hours before her party arrived!! We also found out that everyone was given a king size bed in their room. I insisted that we were to have 2 beds and was given such a room but it cost us $30 each more. The room was old and dirty. I could not believe that the guy working the desk was so proud of himself for giving us such "a DEAL"!! The next morning as we were having our breakfast, we were entertained by the birds, landing on the tables and eating customers meals. No one working there seemed to mind. The rooms were not cheap and NOT worth it at all.

Have stayed here for the last six years and it is always been shabby. The rooms are old however clean. The bathrooms are straight out of the 70sThe upper levels have good views if you are on the left side of the building.The foyer has just had a make over pity the rooms haven't. The location is great. The building was having the balconies painted so there were ropes and hoists outside the room sometimes blocking the view.

We were booked in here by our travel company as part of a deal, without really knowing what we were getting till we got there. The location is great - right in the centre of Waikiki, but the hotel is really not that great, being rather old and tired. We were put on the 18th floor of the main block, directly facing the huge hole in the ground that is the massive building site next door. The noise from there was absolutely intolerable (crashing, banging, beeping) making it impossible to rest or sleep, even with the windows closed. We asked to move rooms immediately and had the most enormous run-around from the front-desk staff, who came up with various (and ever-changing) excuses as to why this was not possible. We involved the rep from our holiday company, who got on to the hotel's senior management. Eventually, after 24 hours and one dreadful night, we were moved to a much better-located room. This was in the small block facing the pool, and with an ocean view over the top of the hotel across the road. Our room was comfortable and well-appointed, if a little in need of a refurb. The bathroom was small, but OK, with bath & shower, but a sliding door. The pool is large and deep, and there are plenty of sun-loungers and fresh towels (you get cards for your towels). There is internet access in the lobby lounge, travel desk for tours and all the usual facilities. We generally enjoyed the rest of our stay, but the initial experience was REALLY bad. Would not go back there after the way we were treated.

We stayed there for our honeymoon for 1 week and were utterly disappointed to be put into a room with a view of the car park, terribly old bathroom in 70s style and broken furniture. We appreciate the upgrade that we received upon complaint but even the new room was marginally newer. Overall it was way over-priced and no value for money. The only win was the location in the heart of Waikiki.

We stayed here for a week for my cousin's wedding in town. This hotel was great! The hotel is located in a central location to many shops, restaurants, and Waikiki Beach. The beds were very comfortable and the food was delicious. There was always plenty of seating at the pool and an added bonus was having staff offer cool towels and ice pops while glistening in the sun! Great nightly entertainment while sipping on Chi Chi tropical drinks were fantastic! Can't wait to come back!

I reserved a "partial ocean" view, which turned out to be very partial - a small view between buildings. We were on the construction side of the tower; the trucks another reviewer heard at 5:00a are actually the garbage trucks in the area - the construction workers start around 7:00a. We choose this hotel for its location and we weren't disappointed. A word of caution - the hotel, like much of Waikiki, is busy much of the night. We heard yelling from some of the surrounding balconies and someone mistook our room for theirs during the night as they tried to enter through our door. It is pricey considering the condition of the hotel, but location was the overriding factor for us. The bed was awesome!

I always read reviews before staying somewhere and this place did have a few knockers but for the deal we got on Wotif we thought we would give it a go and take some tips that were passed on by other Trippos . Get a high ocean view room facing towards Diamond head and you cant go wrong . Awesome views , the rooms were in good condition and the beds were super comfy. Sure the hotel is being updated but this is really not a problem unless you are a bit stuck up. Everything is close , beaches , shops , drinking holes and the staff were great . Spent 10 days here and loved every minute of it.

The hotel is under going a facelift. The lobby and banquet areas are under construction now. Hopefully, the rooms are to follow with fresh paint and updated bathrooms. The beds are still the best for a good night's sleep when you are traveling. The staff continues to excel at customer service. I had a light dinner at the pool bar and was surprised by how good it was. The only problem is they offer no valet parking. You must park yourself and beware that the garage has no elevator/escalator - stairs only. This can be difficult with luggage and a brief case. Looking forward to when the property is done with the renovation.

Had plans to be torn down and rebuilt. Instead, repainted lobby and put new furniture in lobby area. It's like putting lipstick on a pig! Some rooms are like a closet, furniture is as old as the hills!

Altho the room was a bit small it was nice. Parking was FREE, which made our stay pleasant. Tge staff was friendly n helpful. The terrace restaurants' food (breakfast) was delectable. I especially liked that kings alley was right across from us, so we could shop. Made new friend at the ice cream shop of kins alley (village now). Good hotel for overniters.
user_name:
Harriet Nina C
Pahoa, Hawaii, United States

review_body: Our first trip to Honolulu so wasn't sure what to expect. The location of the hotel is good, we enjoyed a inter-connecting room with two doubles and one king, the rooms are large, clean but tired as well, an ocean view room partially not there as a good part of the view is blocked by the buildings across the road. The pool area is nice. We enjoyed an evening meal in the restaurant. We found some staff excellent whilst others just trying to get the job done. The morning paper was a treat and the gym was a big hit.

The room I was put in is really like a motel room. The washing base in the bathroom was the kind of metal one without any cabinet underneath, like those ones you can find in some public loo. There were also strange smell from the shower curtain. The air-con was next to the bed, blowing directly to your body. We had to keep the sliding door closed to avoid the noise from outside. Enough has been said by other comments about their compulsory "Hotel Fee" per day. I simply don't understand. The good thing about this hotel is the location and the staff. Bottom line: Sheraton, If you put me in a motel room, can you please charge me the motel price?

When I came this spring, I was so happy to still be able to get a nice room here at a great AARP/Kama'aina rate. They have delayed knocking down part of the older towers until next year so I enjoyed my stay again, as I have many times in the past. It is so easy to park your car in the parking garage. The front bellmen are great in holding your baggage till you check in after parking your vehicle. Again, I am a resident of the Big Island and my husband is a park ranger here, so we are always treated special and get nice rooms, no matter what side or floor they are on. And getting the complimentary alcoholic or non-alcoholic drinks coupons is a very nice thing down at the bar and watch sports on the big TV in the lobby or by the bar. Some people need to just enjoy the fact that they are in Hawaii, great ocean view area, a famous cultural area of Princess Ka'iulani, I got to be a part of the Spam Jam festival on this trip with great music and entertainment, there are plenty of things to see and do all around downtown and not that far to Ala Moana, go across the street for fun by getting your free beach chair from the pool people. No complaints from me about this place at all!!

The set up is very poor, old and nothing available. It is work paid, otherwise I will not stay there. Busy as other US hotels, rooms is small and old. Except it is at the good location, nothing else for me to like this hotel.

Our group of 32 stayed here May 29-30. They are in the process of renovating the hotel and it is looking very up to date. The rooms were very nice and clean. We ate the breakfast buffet and even though it was a bit pricey it was very good. The hotel is located right across the street from Waikiki Beach. The hotel provided towels and beach chairs for up to take to the beach I understand there is a resort fee but our group was not charged this fee. We enjoyed our stay very much.

Look the staff there are fantastic and the hotel is going through a long slow process of renovation, but in the process nothing worked. The Air con did not work properly, the door locks continually locked us out, waiting in the hall for security to let us in became the routine, even at two in the morning. The rooms are so tired and the furniture that is worn out has been replaced by chairs? (putting a drink on the bedside chair is a challenge let me tell you). Little stuff like lights that didn't work and the in room safe that had a mind of it's own. I am sounding very negative, but the staff were fantastic and in the long run this will again become a beautiful hotel, just not in june 2014.
user_name:
Kodi B
Gold Coast, Queensland, Australia

review_body: We stayed here for a 3 night layover on the way from UK to Truk Lagoon, the hotel had been booked for us by a third party, on our arrival we were checked in quite quickly but were not happy to be informed that there was a $23 per night 'resort tax' that gave some benefits such as unlimited access to the internet on the hotels public computers, but that there was no option to opt out of that service unless it was done so at the time of booking, Check for this if an agent is booking it for you and if are booking it yourself be sure to ask about this, what you are getting for it and if you are likely to get use of it during your stay.Breakfast was not included in our package, the cost of eating in for breakfast at this hotel is in our estimations quite expensive so try and check menus beforehand.We opted to find a nearby restaurant that served a breakfast buffet that was more reasonably priced and provided good portions, be advised that the target market in this region is the Asia Pacific nations so you will struggle to find too much in the way of familiar dishes around unless you spend your life in a sushi bar.Our first room overlooked a burger King restaurant which was pumping out cooking fumes and noise, also on that side of the building was where all the buses and coaches went past, hissing air brakes and horns blasting is not what you want to hear at night after a long series of flights, then in the morning the road works started really early.perhaps not much the hotel can do about external noise other than upgrade the double glazing to keep the noise out, but if you are seeking a quiet room the floors overlooking the front of the hotel are to be avoided.The room its self was tidy but tired looking and the aircon was very noisy, the choice was be cool and don't sleep due to the noisy unit or be warm and don't sleep because you are too hot, not much of a choice really.In the morning I asked at reception to change rooms as we had hardly been able to get any sleep due to all the noise issues inside and out, I eventually accepted a room on the 6th floor that overlooked the pool, this was much further away from the road and had a better aircon unit not being as noisy, the room still had a tired look about it but it was well furnished and reasonably comfortable, we slept quite well that night.The reception staff were friendly and quite helpful although that morning most of my dealings were with the duty manager who dealt with my points in a good natured manner, probably helped by my likewise good natured approach to the issues.The pool area is expansive and well catered for by a pool bar and plenty of sun beds and patio tables and chairs.Night time brings a new dimension to the street outside the hotel, there were at least 4 or 5 prostitutes loitering near the hotel lobby, not far off were their pimps keeping an eye on things, not the kind of scene most people want to have in their faces.The hotel is well positioned for Waikiki Beach and there is plenty to see and do in the area.We took the opportunity to take a tour to Pearl Harbour to the Arizona memorial, this was a good value and moving trip, one to be recommended, we also took a tour up into the country side to try and find the 'real Hawaii' The scenery is stunning but the original Hawaiian culture seems to have been largely lost to commercialism, the only grass skirts and Hawaiian dancing was of the 'manufactured for the tourists' variety at some of the hotels and clubs to remind us of times sadly long since passed.Overall this hotel doesn't live up to the Sheraton brand name, although it was showing signs of being upgraded while we were there with the lobby having a facelift, hopefully this will extend to the rooms in the near future.Its an adequately appointed hotel but nothing too grand to get excited about, it does the job and the more expensive suites and rooms might be very different to what we experienced.Some people will be perfectly happy here others perhaps not so, as with all reviews on here its all a matter of perception and expectations of the writers

My husband and I stayed here last September. It was out first trip together without our three children and i was already really nervous at the idea of leaving themBehind. When we were planing this trip we wanted to stick to a budget with accommodation and the sheraton princess seemed liked the perfect option. How could we go wrong with such a major international hotel group. To our major surprise, we were very very wrong. I remember getting out of the cab and walking Into the reception area and just wanting to cry. It took 35 mins before we were served and another 25 min to check us in. Taking deep breathes I was telling myself it will get better. Again I was so very wrong. The actual hotel is very old and outdated. There is a smell that lingers around the hotel and its not very pleasant. The pictures I saw of the sheraton princess when researching hotels in Waikiki were quiet nice and the hotel did look old but not outdated. When we walked into our room it took me a while to take everything in. The bed was messed up as if some one had been sitting on it, there were stains on the wall and in the corners on the floor there were dust balls with hair,the smell was horrendous, which was coming from sewage from the bathroom, the furniture was so old and worn out it was unbelievable!!I cried and cried. My husband who is a typical male and nothing bothers him was in shock as well. I went straight to the front desk and asked to speak to the manager. He was polite but seemed unfazed at the fact that I was so upset and that made me angry. He said the best he could do was give us vouchers for dinner that night and that I should understand that I have not booked a new and modern hotel. That made me more angry and I demanded that I speak to someone who can do something. I then was speaking to another manager explaining everything all over again and said if she could not help me that I would like a full refund and would go somewhere else. She then popped up her shoulders and asked me to wait a minute she then came back and told me she had found us another room that would be a lot more pleasant for our stay. We were moved to another room on a higher level. It was nice, still outdated and old but a lot more cleaner than the other room. The Resturant there is horrible, we used our dinner voucher there and all I could eat was bread rolls the food is just terrible and cold. My husband, who again is the most laid back person could not manage to put anything in his mouth. The pool is nothing like the photos I saw on their website. It looks as if some disease is brewing in their, the colour of the water is quiet scary, needless to say we never used the pool. I would defiantly go back to Hawaii but never go back to the sheraton princess, it really ruined my holiday, it was so upsetting to me that we paid so much for the accommodation and it was really a 2 star hotel. Please just be aware of the photos on their website, they are really deceiving and photo shopped. It is nothing like it seems on the website.

Hotel: The hotel and my room looked very old. I was told by some people at the hotel that the hotel will be remodeled sometime in August. Hopefully, this is going to happen as the status it was in when I stayed there didn't, in my opinion, live up to the Sheraton name.Staff: Extreme inconsistency when it came to the quality of staff service.Let's talk about the good service:My housekeeper Belinda was very thorough in her service. She was also very friendly and helpful. There was a lady at the front desk and I think her name is Erin. She was also very helpful and friendly.The Bad: I was in line at the front desk behind two Japanese ladies waiting to be served. There were two clerks there at the time and one was assisting some other customers. The only lady who was available did not acknowledge our existence in any way. First, she was busy talking with another staff. Then she disappeared into a room, completely ignoring our presence. We were all shocked as to how she treated people. There was also another male clerk (at another time) who was very rude. Again, I couldn't believe I was staying at a Sheraton!There was a Burger King right across the street from the hotel. But the food was very expensive. I recall a combo meal cost me about US$10. There were some other restaurants in the same shopping complex. And, of course, they cost more than Burger King.Fortunately, there was a food court (about a 15 - 20 minute walk) from the hotel. The food was not really cheap either. If you're in a budget and want to try something local and reasonable, I would suggest going to a ABC store (there were several near the hotel) and purchased a Musubi. Some musubi comes with spam; while there are those that come with chicken etc. (Different ABC stores carry different kinds of musubi. Depending on how big your appetite is, one musubi can be a meal. You can ask the clerk at ABC to heat up the musubi for you. Also, go early as choices can be limited if you're late.All in all, if it's not for the few "nice" employees at Sheraton, I would have given this hotel a "poor" overall rating. Hopefully, the hotel and some employees' attitudes, services... can be improved ASAP.

We had the chance to stay at this hotel. It is in a nice location. Close to a lot of shopping and also the many street acts at night. To me Waikiki is similar to Las Vegas with the street shows. On some nights, there was live hawaiian music near the pool which was a nice touch. The koi ponds near the front entrance were small but nice. The kids enjoyed it. For those who are going to take tours with Roberts hawaii/ booked their trips through Costco, the bus pick up is across the street next to the Hyatt. Unfortunately the international market closed down which was only steps away. This was a decent place to go if you wanted to shop and bargain with vendors for souvenirs and other Hawaiian goods. Similar to the swap meet or flea market. Now for the rooms, they were a little dated. After all it IS one of the older hotels in waikiki. We had a partial ocean view facing Diamond Head and it was plenty a view from the private balcony. There are plenty of restaurants nearby and also the Royal Hawaiian shopping area almost right across the street. Overall this hotel is decent because of its location but the rooms do need some upgrading.

This is an older hotel, our room was part ocean view 27th floor. Bathroom is reminiscent of the 70's but was very clean and everything worked. Check in/out was quick, too. Room was a good size, not cramped. Their in-house dining on ground floor, Pikake Terrace is nice with good menus and service. Bar and Pool adjacent.

Great experience, Andy at arrival was hospitable, a lobby refresh that looks great and relaxes you. A resort charge that covers parking, welcome beverage, wireless access, bottle water; that's convenience and a good deal! Eddy was helpful when I called for some requests, made life easy.

Had wonderful stay. We had a partial ocean view and overlooked the pool. Very relaxing. The street noise was loud but it didn't bother either one of us. The beds were so comfortable.Housekeeping is not great and rooms do need to be re decorated. They were doing renovations to the lobby during our stay. We are planning on staying here again next year.

We thought this was a very nice hotel, although it was a little outdated. The rooms were a nice size, the beds were comfortable and the whole hotel was nice and clean. Its location was ideal for shopping, eating and walking the beach. The staff was very friendly and helpful. I would stay there again.
user_name:
Jennie G
Hopewell, Illinois, United States

review_body: My husband and I just returned from our anniversary trip after staying a week at this hotel. We both have very mixed feelings about all of it, however its best to list out the good and the unfortunate items:Positives:- Location – it really is a 5 minute walk to the beach. I wouldn't even say 10 minutes…perhaps if you are really slow. The convenience and reduction of cost in not being right on the beach is well worth it, as you can even walk through the hotel across the way to get to beach if you want to.- We had a “high tower ocean view” – floor 15. It was a nice view, unfortunately somewhat blocked by neighboring properties, but there’s not much you can do about that no matter how high you go. Balcony is large and it was relaxing to sit and see the ocean, or at night…the city lights up the hills on the other side. The “high tower ocean view” rooms fortunately do not face the neighboring properties under construction, so we lucked out.- Room was clean and housekeeping staff did a GREAT job making up the room each day and replenishing soap, paper, water, etc. They were also friendly and greeted us each morning as we left.- Bell staff was not especially friendly, however they were fast and accommodating. We didn't have to wait much at all for our bags, or for a cab to be hailed. They do an efficient job.- Bed and pillows were clean and comfortable – no issues here. Bathroom was also clean with fresh towels each day.- Fridge was decent. Wish there was a microwave, however you can get one for an extra fee.
